Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit not dug to ground. Quick pit to test stability of SWB from storm on 20200807.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Cracking; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Well bonded snowpack except for bond of DF above MF at surface. High TG will slow the bonding of these layers. Keep an eye on this in regards to upcoming storm. MF at 130cm should Drain and Freeze overnight creating a very strong bridging layer. At this elevation the lower pack is still dry but at lower elevations the entire pack is moist and Isothermal. Weak layers in lower pack did not produce a Propagation result from multiple tests and with the temperatures in the lower pack they will continue to stabilise.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Well consolidated pack at present, this is some of the weakest snow on the hill. Majority of the pack is healing, expect FC to develop near surface. Biggest concern is to see the new storm snow coming in bonds with the old surfaces. Old SH layer found and produced some results, none propagating - sticks together when compacted. Unlikely to be found anywhere else on the hill, and unlikely to be triggered even with large Xe.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit not dug to ground, Impenetrable Ice layer at 33cm down unknown thickness.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: SH layer very obvious mid pack, 10mm needle like crystals, I believe they have been lightly rained on and refrozen from the 26/6 rain event. There were no failures on this layer with two ECTs and it was very hard to even break the block off with my shovel and when it did break it was irregular and non planar. Acting more like a MF layer. 1F hardness is a guesstimate. Snow still moist just above ground.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Recent activity on similar slopes; We skied slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in Well tracked slope. Rounding facets around rain crust are clear and appear to have be previously affected by rain in the pack. the layer of most concern is mostly made up of RGxf but also some buried surface hoar present in this layer. DHxr are a solid mass pencil thick. they appear to have been moist and subsequently have dried out you can still see DH forms once you break this layer up. Coundnt add tests properly so will write in by hand.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Went to investigate report of Nc Sz 2.5 Sp ~1900m that occured on 200713 in the Doolans. Crown 50-200cm deep, 100m wide going 200m long MR. Avalanche seems to have been triggered in a shaded SW asp while we dug in the crown wall facing E which could explain ECTX.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Mid slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Quick test pit dug on towers 1 lee to the s1/4 loading of the previous 48hrs. this is representative of conditions across the summit lee to the S 1/4. 150m below the conditions change dramatically due to limited snow. This low elevation north snowpit reminds us that the recent warming at the start of April has not transitioned the north, shady slopes to the spring regime yet. This zone will need to adjust during the next significant warming cycle.

Deep and strong mature snowpack in this zone. Upper meter consists of April snowfall with frozen crust 40cm below the surface. Strong now but if warm up occurs low density surface snow will consolidate into a slab and if crust softens, avalanches are more likely.
13 cm new snow on road

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Elevator Shaft, pit located at tree line sheltered from cross wind loading, no ski tracks in pit. Warmer winter than usual in the Rockies, a couple of rain events occured in January and February. Strong mid-snowpack with no shears at crust interfaces. Upper snowpack is bonding well with broken shears at 160cm.
BedÃ¶m drevsnÃ¶flak

little to no recent activity feb 23 crust on E and flat slopes to at least 2200m

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Unusual direction of wind (NNE), obvious signs of wind loading on unusual features.
BedÃ¶m drevsnÃ¶flak

20200402 was a warm day, and last night temperatures dropped significantly. There was lots of evidence of wet loose slides from yesterday's warm temps. but today the snow remains a mix of crust in the trees and a thin soft surface in patches in the direct sun.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Fatality site. Accident occurred April 1. Data collected immediately following rescue/recovery on April 2. Crown varied from 4 inches to four feet. Slab propagated along exposed ridge. Formed from recent wind loading. Although deep in spots did not extend far down slope (had no stauchwall). Slab carried victim a long distance and buried him. Slab faced south to southeast. Bedsurface was a slicker sun crust just down slope of the crown.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Maa kivirakkaa. ITL vesiarvo/bulk density testi 1 putki/32 cm/92. Shear frame testi 62 cm pohjasta 3 laatikkoa/4,8 kg.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
We skied slope
We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Failures at 266cm and 260cm occurred simultaneously. At the 260cm interface found intact rounded stellars and chains of rounded NSFs.

Pit location is deep and strong with increased layering in the upper meter. Two frozen melt freeze crusts have weak snow below them but while the crusts are frozen they are strong and provide stability. A strong warming period could soften the crusts and decrease stability.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowmobile triggered avalanche. It broke on top of crust 53 cm down under the new snow. Couldn't find any weak snow in the crown. In another location nearby we could find slightly softer snow on top of the crust and got ECTP25 and 22 on top of that crust. No other signs of instability seen.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: There were some storm layers of varying hardnesses but they have settled and are no longer evident. Most of the new snow is right side up now and well bonded. Other locations may have weak layer of soft new snow but we couldn't find them today.
